revision.text:
{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Lin Daoqian | honorific_suffix = | image = <!-- filename only, no "File:" or "Image:" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] --> | image_upright = | image_size = <!-- DISCOURAGED per WP:IMGSIZE. Use image_upright. --> | alt = | caption = | native_name = 林道乾 | native_name_lang = Chinese | pronunciation = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name above --> | birth_date = 16th century | birth_place = [[Teoswa]] region, [[Guangdong]], [[Ming China]] | disappeared_date = <!-- {{disappeared date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (disappeared date then birth date) --> | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = ''unknown'' | death_place = [[Patani]], [[Siam]] | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | burial_place = <!-- may be used instead of resting_place and resting_place_coordinates (displays "Burial place" as label) --> | burial_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = Pirate | years_active = | era = | employer = | organization = | agent = <!-- Discouraged in most cases, specifically when promotional, and requiring a reliable source --> | known_for = | notable_works = <!-- produces label "Notable work"; may be overridden by |credits=, which produces label "Notable credit(s)"; or by |works=, which produces label "Works" --> | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = <!-- Net worth should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | height = <!-- "X cm", "X m" or "X ft Y in" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | weight = <!-- "X kg", "X lb" or "X st Y lb" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | criminal_charge = <!-- Criminality parameters should be supported with citations from reliable sources --> | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = <!-- Use article title or common name --> | partner = <!-- (unmarried long-term partner) --> | children = | parents = <!-- overrides mother and father parameters --> | mother = <!-- may be used (optionally with father parameter) in place of parents parameter (displays "Parent(s)" as label) --> | father = <!-- may be used (optionally with mother parameter) in place of parents parameter (displays "Parent(s)" as label) --> | relatives = | family = | callsign = | awards = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''Lin Daoqian''' ({{zh|t=林道乾|poj=Lîm tō-khiân|p=Lín Dàoqián|w=Lin Tao-ch'ien}}, [[Malay language|Malay]]: Tok Kayan, Thai: ลิ้มโต๊ะเคี่ยม), also written as '''Lim Toh Khiam''' and '''Vintoquián''',<ref name="kenji"/><ref>{{cite journal|url= https://espace.library.uq.edu.au/view/UQ:240255 |title=From Melayu Patani to Thai Muslim: The spectre of ethnic identity in southern Thailand|author=Patrick Jory |journal=South East Asia Research|volume= 15|issue= 2|pages= 255–279 |jstor=23750846}}</ref> was a Chinese pirate and trader of [[Teochew people|Teochew]] origin. He led pirate attacks along the coast of [[Guangdong]] and [[Fujian]], but they were driven to [[Taiwan]] by the [[Ming dynasty]] navy commanded by [[Yu Dayou]]. He later moved to South East Asia where he traded and engaged in piracy. He became established in [[Patani]] where he died.<ref name="ong-webb">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uxOwGMibTsMC&pg=PA236|title=Piracy, Maritime Terrorism and Securing the Malacca Straits|editors= Graham Gerard Ong-Webb |page=236 |publisher=ISEAS Publishing |date=30 June 2007|isbn= 978-9812304179}}</ref>
==Life== Lin was of [[Teochew people|Teochew]] origin, and he was described as being from either [[Chenghai District|Chenghai]] or [[Huilai County|Huilai]] in [[Guangdong]].<ref name="yen">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PIgGCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA57|title=Ethnic Chinese Business In Asia: History, Culture And Business Enterprise |author= Yen Ching-hwang|page=57 |publisher= World Scientific Publishing Company|isbn=9789814578448 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xKfUBLmQJfwC&pg=PT66#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Guangdong and Chinese Diaspora: The Changing Landscape of Qiaoxiang |author= Yow Cheun Hoe |publisher= Routledge |date=2013 |isbn=9781136171192 }}</ref> Later he moved to [[Quanzhou]], [[Fujian]].<ref name="tamaki"/> Lin was part of the [[Jiajing wokou raids|''wokou'' piratical activity]] that plagued the Chinese coast during the reign of the Ming [[Jiajing Emperor]] (1522–1566). He attacked [[Zhao'an County|Zhao'an]] in 1563, where he was said to have burnt hundreds of houses killing thousands.<ref name="ong-webb"/> In response, the Ming navy led by Yu Dayou drove Lin away first to [[Penghu islands]], later to [[Beigang, Yunlin|Beigang]], Taiwan. Yu then occupied Penghu, but did not pursue Lin to Taiwan.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-981-10-2248-7_2 |author= Wong Young-tsu|date=2017|chapter= Unrest on the China Coast|title= China’s Conquest of Taiwan in the Seventeenth Century|publisher= Springer, Singapore |doi=10.1007/978-981-10-2248-7_2|isbn=978-981-10-2248-7|page=25 }}</ref> Lin was said to have stayed in [[Takau]] for a while . According to Taiwanese accounts, Lin slaughtered many of the natives in Taiwan, using their blood as [[caulking|caulk]] for his ships.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5656984g/f103.image|page=5 |title=L'île Formose : histoire et description|author=Camille Imbault-Huart |date=1893 }}</ref>
Lin escaped to [[Champa]], but after another defeat, he went to [[Luzon]] in the Philippines.<ref name="kenji">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-BU0E4XNa5IC&pg=PA80 |title=Elusive Pirates, Pervasive Smugglers: Violence and Clandestine Trade in the Greater China Seas|editor= Robert J. Antony| author=Igawa Kenji |publisher=Hong Kong University Press |date=1 June 2010|isbn= 978-9888028115 |page=80}}</ref> By 1567, he was again raiding along the coast of China, and in 1568, and the Ming authority placed a bounty on Lin in an attempt to capture him.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.epress.nus.edu.sg/msl/reign/long-qing/year-2-month-9-day-29 |title=Long-qing: Year 2, Month 9, Day 29 |work=Southeast Asia in the Ming Shi-lu: an open access resource |translator=Geoff Wade |publisher=Asia Research Institute and the Singapore E-Press, National University of Singapore }}</ref> Lin was reported to have 5,000 followers in July 1569.<ref name="bradley"/> At some point he was said to have been attacked by another pirate chief [[Limahong|Lin Feng]], who captured 55 of his ships.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xmw_AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA7 |title= Mendoza's Historie of the Kingdome of China, Volume 2|page=7 }}</ref> Ming records state that Lin was "most crafty and cunning",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.epress.nus.edu.sg/msl/reign/long-qing/year-3-month-7-day-23 |title=LLong-qing: Year 3, Month 7, Day 23 |work=Southeast Asia in the Ming Shi-lu: an open access resource |translator=Geoff Wade |publisher=Asia Research Institute and the Singapore E-Press, National University of Singapore }}</ref> and would alternately rebel and swear allegiance to the Ming authority.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.epress.nus.edu.sg/msl/reign/long-qing/year-3-month-6-day-1 |title=Long-qing: Year 3, Month 6, Day 1 |work=Southeast Asia in the Ming Shi-lu: an open access resource |translator=Geoff Wade |publisher=Asia Research Institute and the Singapore E-Press, National University of Singapore }}</ref> It was reported in 1573 that he had rebelled, and fled to find sanctuary in a foreign country.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.epress.nus.edu.sg/msl/reign/wan-li/year-1-month-5-day-14 |title=Wan-li: Year 1, Month 5, Day 14 |work=Southeast Asia in the Ming Shi-lu: an open access resource |translator=Geoff Wade |publisher=Asia Research Institute and the Singapore E-Press, National University of Singapore }}</ref> He settled in [[Côn Sơn Island|Pulo Condore]] in 1574.<ref name="bradley">{{cite journal |url=http://www.siamese-heritage.org/jsspdf/2001/JSS_096_0c_Bradley_PiracySmugglingTradeInRiseOfPatani.pdf |title=Piracy, Smuggling, and Trade in the Rise of Patani, 1490–1600|author=Francis R. Bradley|journal= Journal of the Siam Society |date=2008 |volume= 96 |pages=27–50}}</ref> [[File:สุสันต์ ฮารี รายอ.jpg|thumb|[[Krue Se Mosque]] in [[Patani]], claimed by locals to have been built by Lin Daoqian]] By the first half of 1570s, Lin was already operating in the Patani area, and the Ming authority joined force with the Siamese navy as well as using Portuguese ships to combat the pirates.<ref name="wade">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PIDGBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA69#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Ghosts of the Past in Southern Thailand: Essays on the History and Historiography of Patani |editor=Patrick Jory|publisher=NUS Press |date=30 August 2013|isbn= 978-9971696351 |pages=67–69 |author=Geoff Wade }}</ref> In 1578, he established a base in Patani with 2,000 followers and they would dominate the town for some time.<ref name="patani">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PIDGBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA7&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Ghosts of the Past in Southern Thailand: Essays on the History and Historiography of Patani |author=Anthony Reid |editor=Patrick Jory|publisher=NUS Press |date=30 August 2013|isbn= 978-9971696351 |page=7 }}</ref> Ming sources indicate that he attacked Siamese ships but was repelled in 1578, and in 1580 he again attacked Siam but also left Siam later that year.<ref>{{cite journal |title=The "Ming shi-lu" as a Source for Thai History: Fourteenth to Seventeenth Centuries |author=Geoff Wade|journal=Journal of Southeast Asian Studies|volume= 31|number= No. 2 |date=September 2000|pages= 249–294 |jstor=20072252 }}</ref> The Ming authorities tried to capture him while he continued to launch raids against Chinese ships in 1580–81. After 1581 there were no further reports of his piratical activity in Ming sources, suggesting he had retired from raiding and settled in Patani. He obtained a fief and briefly established a small port near Patani, while members of his band gained prominence in the service of Patani's ruler.<ref name="bradley"/> According to the local lore of Patani, he married the daughter of the Sultan, converted to Islam and built a mosque. He died in Patani, said to be due to cannon fire while he was testing cannons he had made.<ref name="perret">{{cite book |author= Geoff Wade|date= 2004|chapter=From Chaiya to Pahang: The Eastern Seaboard of the Peninsula in Classical Chinese Texts|title= Études sur l'histoire du sultanat de Patani|editor=Daniel Perret|publisher=École française d'Extrême-Orient |pages=75–78}}</ref>
==Lore and legends== ===In Taiwan=== There are a number of myths and legends about Lin in Taiwan. It was said that while anchored at [[Kaohsiung|Takau]], Taiwan in 1563, Lin placed his treasure into eighteen and a half bamboo baskets, hiding them in the surrounding hills, and the [[Shoushan (Kaohsiung)|Takau Hill]] then acquired an alternate name Buried-Gold Hill (埋金山). Another story goes that Lin was told by a [[Taoist]] master that he would be able to conquer all of China if, after he had performed certain tasks in a hundred days, he fired three arrows towards [[Beijing]] on the dawn of the last day. The master gave him 3 magic arrows and a "divine rooster". Lin handed the rooster in the care of his sister Jin-lien (金蓮). On the midnight of last day, Jin-lien inadvertently startled the rooster, causing it to crow. Lin awoke and mistakenly thought that dawn had arrived, immediately firing off three divine arrows with his name towards the imperial capital. The three arrows flew into the imperial palace, striking the dragon throne. However, as it was midnight, the throne was empty. The emperor found the three arrows with Lin's name on them stuck in his throne, realizing that Lin had attempted to kill him, then ordered his troops to attack Lin.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IZznAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA88&lpg=PA88#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=大國海盜|author= 雪珥 |isbn=9789573272069 |pages=87–88 }}</ref>
===In Patani=== [[File:Leng Chu Kiang Shrine in 2014.jpg|thumb|Shrine built in honour of Lim Ko Niao, said to be Lin Daoqian's sister]] The Teochew people of Thailand tell a number of stories about Lin. In one, he was said to have helped the Siamese fight off an [[Đại Việt|Annam]] attack and was thus given the daughter of the king to marry; however, he later angered the king after making a joke about killing the king, and had to flee.<ref name="perret"/> Another story involves the legend of Lin Guniang ([[Lim Ko Niao]]), said to be his sister in this account. Lin Guniang tried to persuade her brother to return to China with her after finding that her brother had married a local woman, converted to Islam as well as building a mosque in Kru Se, Patani. However he refused, fought and defeated her, and she then committed suicide by hanging from a tree.<ref name="bradley"/> Her gravestone, located next to the [[Krue Se Mosque]], is said to have been built by her brother. A shrine in her name exists in Patani and she is worshipped by some Chinese people in southern Thailand.<ref name="tamaki">{{cite journal |url= https://www1.gsec.keio.ac.jp/imgdata/working/5_pdf.pdf |journal=G-SEC Working Paper|title=The prevalence of the worship of Goddess Lin Guniang by the ethnic Chinese in southern Thailand |author=Tamaki, Mitsuko|volume=22 |publisher=Global Security Research Institute|date= December 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PIDGBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA12&lpg=PA12 |title=Ghosts of the Past in Southern Thailand: Essays on the History and Historiography of Patani |editor=Patrick Jory|publisher=NUS Press |date=30 August 2013|isbn= 978-9971696351 |pages=12–13 |author=Anthony Reid }}</ref>
According to ''Phongsawadan muang pattani'' (Chronicle of Pattani), he attempted to cast three bronze cannons to be used in the wars of Patani. After several failures with the third cannon, he offered to sacrifice himself should his attempt be successful, and was blown up while testing the third cannon.<ref name="perret"/> A 19th century Chinese account claims that the ruler of Patani was his descendant.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PIDGBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA75#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Ghosts of the Past in Southern Thailand: Essays on the History and Historiography of Patani |editor=Patrick Jory|publisher=NUS Press |date=30 August 2013|isbn= 978-9971696351 |pages=75–76 |author=Geoff Wade }}</ref>
==Legacy== It is thought that Lin's activity in the area may have influenced the migration of Teochew people to Thailand in later years.<ref name="yen"/> A Dutch merchant [[Olivier van Noort]] described a group of traders from Patani he met in Brunei in 1601 as being Chinese enough to have their own king and used the same laws as in China.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PIDGBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA20#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Ghosts of the Past in Southern Thailand: Essays on the History and Historiography of Patani |author=Anthony Reid |editor=Patrick Jory|publisher=NUS Press |date=30 August 2013|isbn= 978-9971696351 |page=20 }}</ref> Another Dutch report of 1603 by [[Jacob Corneliszoon van Neck|Jacob van Neck]] estimated that there may be as many Chinese in Patani as there were native Malays.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PIDGBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA23#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Ghosts of the Past in Southern Thailand: Essays on the History and Historiography of Patani |author=Anthony Reid |editor=Patrick Jory|publisher=NUS Press |date=30 August 2013|isbn= 978-9971696351 |pages=22–23 }}</ref> Many Malays in Kru Se, Patani claim descent from Lin, although they may have been descendants of his followers who married local women.<ref name="perret"/>
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
[[File:Jacob Hoggard in performance (2008).jpg|thumb|Jacob Hoggard, the lead singer of [[Hedley (band)|Hedley]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://umusic.ca/hedley/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080204194652/http://umusic.ca/hedley/|archivedate=2008-02-04|title=Hedley|publisher=[[Universal Music Group]]|accessdate=2009-01-01}}</ref> finished third on the second season of Canadian Idol.]] ''[[Canadian Idol]]'' was a Canadian [[Interactive television|interactive]] [[Reality television|reality]] [[game show]] series. The series premiered their [[Canadian Idol (season 1)|first season]] in 2003 on [[CTV Television Network|CTV]] and was on air for six seasons.<ref name="info">{{cite web|url=http://www.ctv.ca/idol/gen/ShowInfo.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040209100807/http://www.ctv.ca/idol/gen/ShowInfo.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2004-02-09 |title=Show Info |publisher=[[CTV Television Network]] |work=[[Canadian Idol]] |accessdate=2008-12-29 |df= }}</ref> Based on the American version of the show, ''[[American Idol]]'', it is part of the [[Idol series]]. ''Canadian Idol'' was the most-watched Canadian English-language television series of 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://media.ctv.ca/idol08/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080201004848/http://media.ctv.ca/idol08/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-02-01 |title=CTV Congratulates 2008 Canadian Idol Champ Theo Tams |publisher=[[CTV Television Network]] |work=[[Canadian Idol]] |accessdate=2008-12-29 |df= }}</ref> The show began with a tour across Canada, in which singers [[audition]] in front of four judges: [[Jake Gold]], [[Sass Jordan]], [[Zack Werner]], and [[Farley Flex]].<ref name="info"/> The show was cancelled due to the slowing economy.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20081217/CI6_Idol_rest_081217/20081217?s_name=idol2008&no_ads= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081219144925/http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20081217/CI6_Idol_rest_081217/20081217?s_name=idol2008&no_ads= |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-12-19 |title=Canadian Idol will 'rest' for 2009 |publisher=[[CTV Television Network]] |work=[[Canadian Idol]] |date=2008-12-18 |accessdate=2008-12-29 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/Page/document/v5/content/subscribe?user_URL=https://www.theglobeandmail.com%2Fservlet%2Fstory%2FLAC.20081217.IDOL17%2FTPStory%2FNational&ord=126793003&brand=theglobeandmail&force_login=true|title=Canadian Idol taking a sabbatical next year, CTV says|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=2008-12-17|accessdate=2009-01-04}}{{dead link|date=January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Canadian 'Idol' goes on hiatus|date=2008-12-18|work=Los Angeles Times|page=E2}}</ref>
The show's age requirements allowed people to enter only if they were between 16 and 28 years of age.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/idol/CTVShows/20060202/idol_rules_regs |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060301130329/http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/idol/CTVShows/20060202/idol_rules_regs |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2006-03-01 |title=Canadian Idol Competition Rules – 2006 |publisher=[[CTV Television Network]] |work=[[Canadian Idol]] |accessdate=2008-12-29 |df= }}</ref> During every season, the final round of competition featured ten singers, except for season one when it had eleven finalists. 61 contestants have reached the finals of their respective ''Canadian Idol'' season.<ref name="info"/> Out of the contestants listed, 26 of them were under the age of 20, including three winners and four runners-up. Seventeen finalists came from the [[Provinces and territories of Canada|province]] of [[Ontario]], while [[British Columbia]] and [[Alberta]] each had nine. Alberta had the most Canadian Idol winners with three—[[Kalan Porter]], [[Melissa O'Neil]], and [[Theo Tams]]; [[Newfoundland and Labrador]] had the most runners-up with two—[[Rex Goudie]] and [[Craig Sharpe]]. [[Prince Edward Island]] was the only province to never have had a finalist. There has never been a Canadian Idol finalist from a Canadian territory. [[Toronto]], Ontario was the hometown for the most Canadian Idol finalists with five, followed by [[Abbotsford, British Columbia]] with four. [[Rob James (singer)|Rob James]], [[Dwight d'Eon]], and [[Drew Wright]] were 28 at the time their season's final round began, making them the oldest finalists to have performed; [[Emily Vinette]], Daryl Brunt, [[Craig Sharpe]], and [[Martha Joy]] were 16 at the time their season's final round began, making them the youngest finalists to have been in the finals. __TOC__ {{clear}}

revision.comment: rv unexplained removal
revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=July 2016}} {{Hazara people}} '''[[Hazara people]]''' make up the third largest [[ethnic groups in Afghanistan|ethnic group in Afghanistan]], where they mainly inhabit the [[Hazaristan]] region,<ref name="CIA-af">{{cite web |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/af.html |title= Afghanistan |accessdate=August 7, 2012 |work=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=[[Central Intelligence Agency]]}}</ref> as well as parts of Pakistani Balochistan. The Hazaras in abroad are counted as ''Afghan nationals'' by the [[Government of Pakistan]] and the [[UNHCR]], and some are living in these countries on temporary bases as [[refugee]]s. In addition, other number of Hazaras have immigrated to [[Iran]], [[Australia]], [[Europe]], and [[North America]] in the last several decades also as part of these two intertwined diasporean groupings, as part of the [[Hazara people|Hazara]] and wider [[Afghan diaspora]]. Below is the list of some notable Hazara people.
== Politicians == [[File:Abdul Ali Mazari.jpg|upright|thumb|[[Abdul Ali Mazari]]]] [[File:Ahmad Behzad-600x400.jpg|upright|thumb|[[Ahmad Behzad]] the 2nd deputy of the [[House of the People (Afghanistan)|Afghanistan Parliament]]]] [[File:Karim Khalili in December 2010-cropped.jpg|upright|thumb|[[Karim Khalili]], Former Second [[Vice President of Afghanistan|Vice President]] of [[Afghanistan]]]] * [[Abdul Ali Mazari]] * [[Ustad Muhammad Akbari]] * [[Karim Khalili]] * [[Sultan Ali Keshtmand]] * [[Ramazan Bashardost]] * [[Mohammad Mohaqiq]] * [[Qazi Muhammad Essa]] * [[Habiba Sarabi]] * [[Sima Samar]] * [[Hussain Ali Yousafi]] * [[Muhammad Ali Jawid]] * [[Maryam Monsef]] * [[Abdul Khaliq Hazara (politician)|Abdul Khaliq Hazara]] * [[Akram Yari]] * [[Ahmad Behzad]] * [[Jan Ali Changezi]] * [[Qurban Ali Oruzgani]] * [[Abdul Haq Shafaq]] * [[Sayed Anwar Rahmati]] * [[Azra Jafari]] * [[Sayyid Ali Beheshti]] * [[Shah Gul Rezai]] * [[Sarwar Danish]] * [[Sayed Nasir Ali Shah]] * [[Haji Sayed Hussain Hazara]] * [[Abdul Wahed Sorabi]] * [[Azizullah Royesh]] * [[Ahmad Shah Ramazan]] * [[Dawood Ali Najafi]] * [[Abdul Qayyum Sajjadi]] * [[Ghulam Ali Wahdat]] * [[Muhammad Hussain Sadiqi Nili]] * [[Nasrullah Sadiqi Zada Nili]] * [[Sayed Mustafa Kazemi]] * [[Sayed Mansur Naderi]] * [[Abbas Ibrahim Zada]] * [[Muhammad Arif Shah Jahan]] * [[Sayed Hussein Anwari]] * [[Sayyed Mohammad Eqbal Munib]] * [[Rahila Bibi Kobra Alamshahi]] * [[Zahera Ahmadyar Mawlayee]] * [[Abdul Taleb Zaki]] * [[Asadullah Saadati]]
== Military personnel == [[File:General Muhammad Musa Khan Hazara.jpg|upright|thumb|Gen. [[Muhammad Musa]] served as the [[Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)|Chief of Army Staff]] of [[Pakistan]] from 1958 to 1966.]] * [[General Khudaidad|Lt. Gen. (Rt) Khudaidad Khan]] * [[Muhammad Musa|General Muhammad Musa Khan Hazara]] * [[Samad Ali Changezi|Flight Lt. Samad Ali Changezi]] * [[Sharbat Ali Changezi|Air Marshal Sharbat Ali Changezi]] * [[Saira Batool]] * [[Younus Changezi|Rt. Col. Younus Changezi]] * [[Murad Ali Murad|Lt. General Murad Ali Murad]] * [[Kobra Ali]]
== Religious figures == * [[Mohammad Ishaq Al-Fayyad]] * [[Mohaqiq Kabuli]] * [[Ismail Balkhi]]
== Writers, poets and people in the media == [[File:Faiz Muhammad Katib.jpg|upright|thumb|[[Faiz Mohammad Katib Hazara]] (1862–1929) [[Afghanistan|Afghan]] historian, writer and intellectual.]] * [[Faiz Mohammad Katib Hazara]] * [[Hassan Poladi]] * [[Ismail Balkhi]] * [[Haji Kazim Yazdani]] * [[Kamran Mir Hazar]] * [[Basir Ahang]] * [[Mohsin Changezi]] * [[Sayed Askar Mousavi]] * [[Ali Baba Taj]] * [[Ali-Shir Nava'i]] * [[Ali Mohaqiq Nasab]] * [[Qasim Akhgar]]
=== Scientists === * [[Sayed Hassan Akhlaq]] * [[Abbas Noyan]]
=== Actors === * [[Atossa Leoni]] * [[Ahmad Khan Mahmoodzada]] * [[Shaima Rezayee]] * [[Hussain Sadiqi]] * [[Abid Ali Nazish]] * [[Ali Ahmadi (nomad)|Ali Ahmadi]] * [[Nikbakht Noruz]]
=== Singers === * [[Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan]], Pakistani singer, His ancestors were from [[Behsud (Hazara tribe)|Behsudi]] Hazaras of Afghanistan.<ref>[http://www.ariaye.com/dari4/tarikh/qasemi3.html ariaye.com]</ref> * [[Safdar Tawakoli]] * [[Dawood Sarkhosh]] * [[Zahir Howaida]] * [[Elaha Soroor]] * [[Aabey Mirza]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://hazaristantimes.wordpress.com/2008/10/21/abey-mirza/|title=Abey Mirza: Mother of Hazaragi Folk Music|date=2008-10-21|work=Hazaristan Times|access-date=2017-10-02|language=en-US}}</ref> * [[Shakeeb Hamdard]] * [[Mr. Capone-E]]
=== Photographers === * [[Barat Ali Batoor]]
=== Journalists === * [[Malek Shafi'i]]
=== Directors === * [[Burhan Qurbani]]
== Sports ==
=== Football === [[File:Rohullah Nikpai speaking in 2012-cropped.jpg|upright|thumb|[[Rohullah Nikpai]]]] [[File:حسین صادقی.jpg|upright|thumb|[[Hussain Sadiqi]]]] * [[Zohib Islam Amiri]] * [[Moshtagh Yaghoubi]] * [[Mustafa Amini]] * [[Khodadad Azizi]] * [[Roholla Iqbalzadeh]] * [[Rahmat Akbari]]
=== Boxing === * [[Haider Ali (boxer)|Haider Ali]] * [[Abrar Hussain (boxer)|Abrar Hussain]] * [[Hamid Rahimi]]
=== Karate === * [[Meena Hazara]]
=== Taekwondo === * [[Rohullah Nikpai]]
=== Judo === * [[Friba Razayee]]
=== Wrestling === * [[Wakil Hussain Allahdad]]
=== Wushu === * [[Hussain Sadiqi]]
=== Martial arts === * [[Ali Ahmadi (nomad)|Ali Ahmadi]]
== Business == * [[Saad Mohseni]] * [[Fatema Akbari]]
== Others == * [[Abdul Khaliq Hazara (assassin)]]
== See also == * [[List of people from Quetta]] * [[Josiah Harlan]] American military leader and advocate for the Hazara people.
== References == {{reflist|2}}

revision.comment: /* Silver Medal recipients */
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Use British English|date=January 2017}} This is a list of recipients of medals awarded by the [[Royal Aeronautical Society]].
==Individual medal recipients==
===Gold Medal recipients=== * 1909 - [[Wright Brothers|Wilbur and Orville Wright]] * 1910 - [[Octave Chanute]] * 1945 - Air Cdre [[Frank Whittle]] * 1949 - [[Sydney Camm]]<ref>Medallist list published [http://www.aerosociety.com/Assets/Docs/Medals%20and%20Awards/HMA%20-%20List%20of%20RAeS%20Award%20Winners.pdf here].</ref> * 1950 - Sir [[Geoffrey de Havilland]] * 1955 - [[Ernest Hives, 1st Baron Hives]] - "for his outstanding work in the field of aircraft propulsion.".<ref>[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1955/1955%20-%200607.html ''Flight'' 13 May 1955 p607]</ref> * 1957 - [[Robert Lickley]] * 1958 - [[Stuart Davies (engineer)|Stuart Davies]] * 1959 - [[Marcel Dassault]] * 1960 - Sir [[Frederick Handley Page]] * 1964 - [[Ronald Eric Bishop]] * 1967 - [[Stanley Hooker]] * 1977 - [[George Lee (pilot)|George Lee]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Flight International Archive |date=10 December 1977 |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1977/1977%20-%203715.html |accessdate= 9 June 2012 }} </ref> * 1983 - [[Geoffrey Lilley]] * 1986 - [[Ralph Hooper]] * 2009 - [[Henry McDonald (engineer)|Henry McDonald]] * 2012 - [[Elon Musk]] * 2014 - [[Dr Gordon McConnell]] <ref>[http://aerosociety.com/Assets/Docs/Medals%20and%20Awards/2014_RAeS_Medals_and_Awards_Winners.pdf ''2014 RAeS Medals and Awards Winners'']</ref> * 2015 - [[Professor Richard J Parker]] <ref>[http://aerosociety.com/Assets/Docs/Medals%20and%20Awards/2015_WOW_Medals_and_Awards_brochure_Web.pdf ''2015 RAeS Medals and Awards Winners'']</ref>
===Silver Medal recipients=== Winners of the annual Silver Medal of the Royal Aeronautical Society * 1962 - [[Dietrich Küchemann]] * 1967 - [[Charles Joy (engineer)|Charles Joy]] * 1971 - [[John Argyris]]<ref>Medallist list published [http://www.aerosociety.com/Assets/Docs/Medals%20and%20Awards/HMA%20-%20List%20of%20RAeS%20Award%20Winners.pdf here].</ref> * 1991 - [[Roy Dommett]] * 2005 - [[David Southwood|Professor David Southwood]]<ref>Medallist list published [http://www.aerosociety.com/Assets/Docs/Medals%20and%20Awards/HMA%20-%20List%20of%20RAeS%20Award%20Winners.pdf here].</ref> * 2010 - [[Frank De Winne]] * 2011 - [[Professor Terence Jones]] <ref>[http://aerosociety.com/Assets/Docs/Medals%20and%20Awards/2011%20Medals%20and%20Awards%20brochure%20Final.pdf ''2011 RAeS Medals and Awards Winners'']</ref> * 2012 - Robert Smith <ref>[http://aerosociety.com/Assets/Docs/Medals%20and%20Awards/2012_Medals_and_Awards_Brochure.pdf ''2012 RAeS Medals and Awards Winners'']</ref> * 2013 - [[Professor John Denton]] <ref>[http://aerosociety.com/Assets/Docs/2013%20WOW%20Medals%20and%20Awards%20brochure%20v4%20%283%29.pdf ''2013 RAeS Medals and Awards Winners'']</ref> * 2014 - [[Mr Frank Ogilvie]] <ref>[http://aerosociety.com/Assets/Docs/Medals%20and%20Awards/2014_RAeS_Medals_and_Awards_Winners.pdf ''2014 RAeS Medals and Awards Winners'']</ref> * 2014 - [[Mr Robert Saia]] <ref>[http://aerosociety.com/Assets/Docs/Medals%20and%20Awards/2014_RAeS_Medals_and_Awards_Winners.pdf ''2014 RAeS Medals and Awards Winners'']</ref> * 2015 - [[G. Satheesh Reddy]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/india-news/prestigious-award-for-defence-scientist-g-satheesh-reddy-1216883|title=Prestigious Award for Defence Scientist G Satheesh Reddy|date=12 September 2015|work=[[NDTV]]|accessdate=29 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/hyderabad/REeS-Silver-Medal-for-Satheesh-Reddy/2015/09/13/article3025050.ece|title=REeS Silver Medal for Satheesh Reddy|work=[[The New Indian Express]]|accessdate=29 January 2016}}</ref>
==Team medal recipients==
===Team Gold Medalists===
* 2004 - [[SpaceShipOne]] * 2005 - [[A380]] Wing Design Team * 2007 - [[BERP rotor]] development team * 2008 - [[Trent 900]] Engineering Team * 2009 - Vectored-thrust Aircraft Advanced Control (VAAC) Team * 2009 - [[Jules Verne ATV]] Operations Team * 2014 - [[Project Zero]] Team <ref>[http://aerosociety.com/Assets/Docs/Medals%20and%20Awards/2014_RAeS_Medals_and_Awards_Winners.pdf ''2014 RAeS Medals and Awards Winners'']</ref> * 2015 - [[Rosetta Mission]] Team <ref>[http://aerosociety.com/Assets/Docs/Medals%20and%20Awards/2015_WOW_Medals_and_Awards_brochure_Web.pdf ''2015 RAeS Medals and Awards Winners'']</ref>
===Team Silver Medalists===
* 2005 - [[Huygens]] project team * 2008 - Cranfield Aerospace [[X-48]]B UAV * 2010 - [[Mantis UAV]] project team * 2011 - [[HYLAS-1]] team * 2012 - CAMPS development team * 2013 - [[ASTRAEA]] Team * 2014 - Team [[Taranis]] <ref>[http://aerosociety.com/Assets/Docs/Medals%20and%20Awards/2014_RAeS_Medals_and_Awards_Winners.pdf ''2014 RAeS Medals and Awards Winners'']</ref> * 2015 - The [[Beagle 2 Mars Mission]] Engineering Team <ref>[http://aerosociety.com/Assets/Docs/Medals%20and%20Awards/2015_WOW_Medals_and_Awards_brochure_Web.pdf ''2015 RAeS Medals and Awards Winners'']</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Royal Aeronautical Society|medal recipients]] [[Category:Lists of award winners|Royal Aeronautical Society]]

page.title: List of offenders executed in the United States in 2018

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:2018-related lists]] to [[Category:Lists of deaths in 2018]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
This is a '''list of offenders executed in the United States in 2018'''. As of {{date||mdy}}, 2018, twenty-one death row inmates have been executed in the United States. In addition, four inmates are currently scheduled to be executed in December 2018, in three different states. One of them (David Earl Miller) has chosen to die by electrocution.{{Cite web|url=https://deathpenaltyinfo.org/upcoming-executions#year2018|title=Upcoming Executions {{!}} Death Penalty Information Center|website=deathpenaltyinfo.org|language=en|access-date=2018-01-20}} ==List of offenders executed in the United States in 2018== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center; font-size:100%;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="background-color:#FFA200; width:100px;" | Number ! rowspan="2" style="background-color:#FFA200; width:150px;" | Date of execution ! rowspan="2" style="background-color:#FFA200; width:275px;" | Name ! rowspan="2" style="background-color:#FFA200; width:150px;" | Date of birth ! colspan="3" style="background-color:#FFA200; width:200px;" | Age of offender ! rowspan="2" style="background-color:#FFA200; width:100px;" | Gender ! rowspan="2" style="background-color:#FFA200; width:100px;" | Ethnicity ! rowspan="2" style="background-color:#FFA200; width:100px;" | State ! rowspan="2" style="background-color:#FFA200; width:150px;" | Method ! rowspan="2" style="background-color:#FFA200; width:150px;" | Source |- ! style="background-color:#FFA200; width:100px;" | At execution ! style="background-color:#FFA200; width:100px;" | At offense ! style="background-color:#FFA200; width:100px;" | Age difference |- | 1 | {{dts|January 18, 2018}} | |[[Lethal injection]] | {{Cite web|url=https://www.tdcj.state.tx.us/death_row/dr_info/shoreanthony.html|title=Offender Information - Anthony Shore|last=Texas Department of Criminal news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/texas-tourniquet-killer-anthony-allen-shore-lethal-injection-first-execution-of-2018/|title=Texas "Tourniquet Killer" put to death in first execution of 2018|access-date=2018-01-20|language=en}} |- | 2 | {{dts|January 30, 2018}} | {{sortname|William Earl|Rayford|nolink=1}} | {{dts|May 21, 1953}} | 64 | 46 | 18 | Black | {{Cite daughters put to death in nation's 3rd execution of 2018|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|language=English|last=Blakinger|first=Keri|date=February 1, 2018|access-date=2018-02-02}} |- | 4 | {{dts|February revision.text:
{{Infobox writer |name = Potenciano Gregorio |image = |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date |1880|5|18}} |birth_place = [[Santo Domingo, Albay|Lib-og]], [[Albay]], [[Captaincy General of the Philippines]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|1939|2|12|1880|5|18}} |death_place = [[Honolulu]], [[Hawaii]] |other_names = |occupation = Musician |alma_mater = |citizenship = [[Filipino people|Filipino]] }} '''Potenciano Gregorio''', often referred to as '''Potenciano Gregorio Sr.''' (May 19, 1880 to February 12, 1939) was a [[Bikol language|Bicolano]] musician. He was the composer of ''Sarung Banggi'' (One Evening), the most famous song in the [[Bikol language]].
Potenciano Gregorio was born in what was then known as the town of Lib-og (now [[Santo Domingo, Albay|Santo Domingo]]) in the province of [[Albay]] in the [[Philippines]]. His parents were Narciso Gregorio and Canuta Valladolid (some sources spell his mother's name as ''Balladolid''). At an early age he learned to play the violin and was soon recognized for his talent. He subsequently learned to play other instruments such as the bandurria, the guitar, and piano. Later he started writing music for the local church by himself or in collaboration with his older brother Bernardo who organized the local band Banda de Lib-og. Potenciano later became the bandmaster of the same band until he joined the [[Philippine Constabulary Band]] in 1919.
It is claimed that Potenciano Gregorio composed ''Sarung Banggi'' when he was 17 years old. There are different versions as to how he composed this song. Hilario Balilo, the former town mayor stated that the composer wrote the music and lyrics of the song one night after hearing a bird chirping and the leaves rustling. He based this version on information he received from Justo Gregorio, a nephew of Potenciano. Resurrecion Gregorio, a grandson of Potenciano however claimed that the song was written during the 1897 eruption of Mayon volcano and initially the composer wanted to dedicate the song to his then fiancée Dominga Duran whom he later married.
Potenciano Gregorio later sold the rights to the song to [[Constancio de Guzman]].
He also wrote other songs like ''Pusong Tagub nin Sakit'' and ''Hinuyop-hoyop nin Dios''.
In 1919, he joined the Philippine Constabulary band under the tutelage of Col. [[Walter Loving]].
Potenciano Gregorio was among those invited to compete with other musicians during the Golden Gate International Exposition in 1938. However, while he was overseas, he died in 1939 of pneumonia in Honolulu. His remains were brought back to the Philippines and buried in La Loma Cemetery in [[Manila]]. In 2005, his remains were exhumed and brought to his hometown of Santo Domingo where they were reinterred.
In 1961, a fire hit Santo Domingo which destroyed Potenciano Gregorio's ancestral home.
==References== *http://www.inq7.net/globalnation/sec_fea/2004/jan/29-05.htm *http://www.pia.gov.ph/news.asp?fi=p050531.htm&no=26{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gregorio, Potenciano}} [[Category:Filipino musicians]] [[Category:People from Albay]] [[Category:1880 births]] [[Category:1939 deaths]] [[Category:Bicolano people]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Rye Barcott | image = File:Rye Barcott Full Color 2017.jpg | caption = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1979}} | nationality = [[United States|US]] | residence = [[North Carolina]], USA | alma_mater = [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]]
[[Harvard University]] | organization = [[Carolina for Kibera]]
Double Time Capital
[[With Honor]] | occupation = Author
Entrepreneur
U.S. military | title = Cofounder & CEO | spouse = Tracy Barcott | children = | parents = | website = [http://ithappenedonthewaytowar.com ''It Happened on the Way to War''] | footnotes = }} '''Rye Barcott''' (born 1979) is a social entrepreneur and the author of the memoir ''It Happened on the Way to War''. He previously co-founded [[Carolina for Kibera]] and Double Time Capital. He was a human intelligence officer in the [[United States Marine Corps]], achieving the rank of captain. Currently, he is the CEO of [[With Honor]], a new movement led by veterans focused on building a cross-partisan coalition of next-generation veterans in the [[United States Congress]] in order to help fix our America's broken, hyper-polarized politics. ==Background and early life== Barcott was born in Rhode Island. His father attended [[Miami University]] on an [[Reserve Officers' Training Corps]] scholarship and went on to serve in the Marines' [[3rd Reconnaissance Battalion]] during the [[Vietnam War]]. His father left the Marines as a captain after receiving a [[Bronze Star Medal]] and a [[Purple Heart]] in combat. His parents met as graduate students at the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]]. Barcott's mother is a nurse and anthropologist who teaches at the [[University of Rhode Island]].{{cite web|url=http://web.uri.edu/nursing/meet/donna-schwartz-barcott-ph-d-r-n/ |title=Professor Donna Schwartz-Barcott URI profile|publisher=}} Barcott initially applied to the [[United States Naval Academy]] but was turned down. As a result, he instead applied for an NROTC scholarship to the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]]. ==Education== Barcott attended [[East Greenwich High School]]. He graduated in 2001 from the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]], where he studied economics and anthropology. He attended [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|UNC]] on a four-year [[U.S. Marine Corps]] [[NROTC]] Scholarship. In 2009, Barcott graduated with an MPA and MBA from [[Harvard University]] as a Center for Public Leadership Social Entrepreneurship Fellow and George Leadership Fellow. [[Harvard University]] President [[Drew Faust]] appointed him to a two-year term on the [[Harvard]] Endowment's Advisory Committee on Shareholder Responsibility, and he served as a founding member of the movement to create an [[MBA Oath]].{{cite web|url=http://mbaoath.org/about/who-we-are/|title=Who We Are - The MBA Oath|publisher=}} He was elected as a member of the [[Harvard University]] Alumni Association Board of Directors in 2016.{{cite web|title=HAA Board of Directors|url=https://alumni.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/page/HAA%20Board%20for%20web_121417.pdf|website=alumni.harvard.edu|accessdate=26 April 2018}}_ ==Military service== Barcott served five years on active duty in the [[United States Marine Corps|Marine Corps]], where he attained the rank of captain and deployed to [[Bosnia]], the [[Horn of Africa]], and [[Iraq]].[http://www.pritzkermilitary.org/whats_on/pritzker-military-presents/rye-barcott-it-happened-way-war/ Barcott on ''It Happened on the Way to War'' at the Pritzker Military Museum & Library] In 2006, he provided written testimony to the [[Iraq Study Group]] and authored an article about the Iraqi Military Intelligence Academy in [[Proceedings (magazine)|Proceedings]], the professional journal of the U.S. Navy.{{cite web|last1=Barcott|first1=Rye|title="No Torture"-It's a Start|url=https://www.usni.org/magazines/proceedings/2007-07/no-torture—-its-start|website=usni.org|publisher=Proceedings Magazine|accessdate=26 April 2018}} [[ABC World News with Charles Gibson]] covered his work in Kibera and his military service in Iraq and named him a Person of the Week and a 2006 Person of the Year.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/WNT/PersonOfWeek/story?id=2611995&page=1|title=American in Iraq Fights Two Wars at Once|date=4 May 2007|publisher=ABC News}} The ABC World News story quoted him encouraging young Americans to expose themselves "to how the majority of the world lives … and I think it'll make you a lot more appreciative of what you've got … make you a better American and a better global citizen." The [[U.S. Department of Defense]] awarded Barcott with the [[Military Outstanding Volunteer Service Medal]]. The President of the United States appointed him to the [[J. William Fulbright Foreign Scholarship Board]] as a representative of the veteran community.{{cite web|title=President Obama Announces More Key Administration Posts|url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/the-press-office/2012/03/02/president-obama-announces-more-key-administration-posts|website=ObamaWhiteHouseArchives.gov|publisher=The White House, Office of the Press Secretary|accessdate=17 April 2018}} ==Writings== Barcott is the author of the critically acclaimed{{cite news|last=Ghosh |first=Bobby |url=http://globalspin.blogs.time.com/2011/05/23/a-devil-dog-find-his-best-angels/ |title=Do Former Soldiers Make the Best Social Workers? | World | TIME.com |publisher=Globalspin.blogs.time.com |date=2011-05-23 |accessdate=2012-09-18}} memoir ''It Happened on the Way to War'' ([[Bloomsbury Publishing]]). The book's dedication to [[Carolina for Kibera|Carolina For Kibera]] cofounders Salim Mohamed and Tabitha Atieno Festo includes a phrase that captures the central theme of the book: "Talent is universal; opportunity is not." In 2001, Barcott co-edited with Dr. Carolyn Pumphrey ''Armed Conflict in Africa'', a book that analyzed the sources of violence in Africa. His post-9/11 letters with Salim Mohamed were published in Andrew Carroll's ''War Letters: Extraordinary Correspondence from American Wars'' (Scribner, 2001). He contributed to ''Passion and Purpose'', ''27 Views of Charlotte'', and ''65 Successful Harvard Business School Application Essays''. His writing has appeared in [[The Washington Post]],{{cite news|author=Rye Barcott |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/all-americans-have-a-duty-to-honor-memorial-day/2011/05/27/AGvgVNEH_story.html |title=All Americans have a duty to honor Memorial Day |publisher=The Washington Post |date= 2011-05-30|accessdate=2012-09-18}} [[New York Times|The New York Times]],{{cite news|last=Barcott |first=Rye |url=http://kristof.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/05/18/when-it-comes-to-helping-others-just-do-it/ |title=When It Comes to Helping Others: Just Do It - NYTimes.com |publisher=Kristof.blogs.nytimes.com |date=2011-05-18 |accessdate=2012-09-18}} and [[CNN]].{{cite web|last1=Barcott|first1=Rye|title=Why military veterans make great employees|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/OPINION/07/15/barcott.veterans.jobs/index.html|website=CNN.com|accessdate=26 April 2018}} In 2007, he delivered the commencement address to the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill School of Public Health]].{{cite web|title=Commencement weekend: School of Public Health welcomes new alumni|url=https://sph.unc.edu/commencement-weekend-school-of-public-health-welcomes-new-alumni/|website=SPH.UNC.edu|accessdate=17 April 2018}} He is the 2018 commencement speaker for the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]].{{cite web|last1=Cook|first1=Jeni|title=Rye Barcott, social entrepreneur, to speak at UNC-Chapel Hill Commencement|url=https://uncnews.unc.edu/2018/02/15/rye-barcott-social-entrepreneur-speak-unc-chapel-hill-commencement/|website=UNCNews.edu|accessdate=16 April 2018}} As an inaugural [[TED (conference)|TED]] Fellow, he gave a TED speech on "The Power of Participatory Development."{{cite web|url=https://www.ted.com/profiles/114698/fellow|title=Rye Barcott - TED Fellow - TED.com|publisher=}} He is represented by the American Program Bureau and frequently speaks at colleges and high schools. ''It Happened on the Way to War'' was one of four books selected for the TED 2011 Book Club, and was named best nonfiction title in 2011 by the North Carolina Literary and Historical Association.{{cite web|title=North Carolina Literary and Historical Association Award Winners Database|url=https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/18GfAPMi4QjiZZ_HG13UrW1kOzGR9VKzwatUhnNJf5m0/edit#gid=0|website=ncdcr.gov|accessdate=26 April 2018}} In 2011, [[Reader's Digest]] named the book as one of four top nonfiction titles of the year. [[Dartmouth College]] awarded Barcott a Doctorate of Humane Letters in 2016.{{cite web|last1=Silverstein|first1=Hannah|title=Nobel Laureate Leymah Gbowee to Speak at Commencement|url=https://news.dartmouth.edu/news/2016/04/nobel-laureate-leymah-gbowee-speak-commencement|website=News.Dartmouth.edu|accessdate=26 April 2018}} ==Social enterprise and career== ===Carolina for Kibera=== While an undergraduate at the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|UNC]] in 2001, Barcott founded [[Carolina for Kibera]] (CFK) in Kenya with Salim Mohamed and Tabitha Atieno Festo. CFK started as a small inter-ethnic soccer program and medical clinic run out of Festo's ten-by-ten foot shack. Today it is a major affiliated entity of the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]]. More than 5,000 youth participate in its holistic youth programs, and the Tabitha Clinic treats more than 20,000 patients a year in collaboration with the [[U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]].[http://www.smartglobalhealth.org/blog/entry/cdc-carolina-for-kibera-tabitha-health-clinic/ Center For Strategic and International Studies, The Commission on Smart Global Health Policy, August 10, 2009] ===Double Time Capital=== Barcott co-founded Double Time Capital in 2013 as an impact investment firm focused on clean energy and sustainability. As of February 2017, "Double Time has financed 36 solar energy projects, which collectively produce roughly 10% of North Carolina's solar power and power around 30,000 homes in the state."{{cite web|last1=Quittner|first1=Jeremy|title=These Marines Beat the Odds to Build a Solar Energy Fund|url=http://fortune.com/2017/02/22/marines-solar-energy-fund/|website=Fortune.com|accessdate=16 April 2018}} At that time, North Carolina was the second ranked state in the United States based on the cumulative amount of solar electric capacity installed.{{cite web|title=North Carolina Solar|url=https://www.seia.org/state-solar-policy/north-carolina-solar|website=SEIA.org|accessdate=16 April 2018}} ===With Honor=== Barcott co-founded With Honor in 2017 with [[David Gergen]] and other veterans. [[With Honor]] is a cross-partisan movement led by veterans focused on increasing the number of next-generation veterans in Congress in order to advocate for changes in America's politics. With Honor's advisory board includes post-9/11 veterans, Gold Star family members, and other prominent American public figures.{{cite web|title=With Honor Advisors|url=https://www.withhonor.org/about-us/our-advisors|website=WithHonor.org|accessdate=March 30, 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Portal|Biography|United States Marine Corps}} *[http://cfk.unc.edu Carolina for Kibera] *[http://officer.marines.com/marine/quality_citizens/officer_interviews/rye_barcott U.S. Marine Corps Officer “Quality Citizen” Profile of Rye Barcott] *[http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2011/10/lessons-from-a-kenyan-slum/ Harvard Profile] *[http://ithappenedonthewaytowar.com/ ''It Happened on the Way to War''] *{{C-SPAN|Rye Barcott}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Barcott, Rye}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American humanitarians]] [[Category:American male non-fiction writers]] [[Category:American memoirists]] [[Category:American expatriates in Kenya]] [[Category:American Marine Corps personnel of the Iraq War]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Social entrepreneurs]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:United States Marine Corps officers]] [[Category:University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill alumni]] [[Category:American people of Croatian descent]]

revision.comment: Additional information re Olin and Preston Institute; link added; reference added; nonfactual opinion without reference deleted.
revision.text:
'''Col. William Preston''' (December 25, 1729 – June 28, 1783)<ref>Colonel William Preston ''Gravestone,'' Preston Family Cemetery, Smithfield Plantation, Blacksburg, Virginia</ref> played a crucial role in surveying and developing the colonies going westward, exerted great influence in the colonial affairs of his time, ran a large plantation, and founded a dynasty whose progeny would supply leaders for the South for nearly a century.<ref>''The Smithfield Review, Volume XIV,'' "The Fincastle Resolutions," Jim Glanville. page 91</ref> He served in the [[House of Burgesses|Virginia House of Burgesses]], and was a Colonel in the militia during the [[American Revolutionary War]]. He was one of the thirteen signers of the [[Fincastle Resolutions]], a predecessor to the [[United States Declaration of Independence]].<ref>''The Smithfield Review, Volume XIV,'' "The Fincastle Resolutions," Jim Glanville. page 81</ref>
He was a founding [[trustee]] of Liberty Hall (later [[Washington and Lee University]]), when it was made into a college in 1776.<ref name=Lex>Williams, Richard G (2013). Lexington, Virginia and the Civil War. The History Press, 2013. Retrieved online https://books.google.com/books?id=SnlXXMRrD3MC&pg=PA22</ref> [[File:William Preston's Signature.JPG|thumb|alt=Alt William Preston's Signature|William Preston's Signature]]
==Personal life== William Preston was born on Christmas Day, 1729, in [[Limavady]], Ireland, to [[Colonel (U.K.)|Col]]. [[John Preston (settler)|John Preston]] and his wife Elizabeth. Elizabeth's father [[Henry Patton (shipwright)|Henry Patton]] was a prominent shipwright and merchant, and her brother [[James Patton (Royal Navy officer)|James Patton]] served with such distinction in the [[Royal Navy]] that the Crown granted him between 100,000 and 120,000 acres in America to permit [[British colonization of the Americas|British colonization]] beyond the [[Blue Ridge Mountains]].<ref>Preston, F.L. "[http://www.suddenlink.net/pages/fpreston/sfjohn.htm John Preston 1699-1747]". 2007. Accessed 28 September 2013.</ref> The family immigrated to [[Augusta County, Virginia|Augusta Co]]., [[Virginia Colony|Virginia]], in 1738 on James's ship.<ref>Osborn, Richard Charles. ''William Preston of Virginia, 1727–1783: The Making of a Frontier Elite.''1990, Dissertation, University of Maryland College Park. pages 9–10</ref> Subsequent [[French and Indian War|French and Indian resistance]] and [[Royal Proclamation of 1763|reversal of British policy]] limited the impact of the family's grants, but [[Prestonsburg, Kentucky]], was named in John's honor by its later founders.<ref name=ren>Rennick, Robert. ''Kentucky Place Names'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=3Lac2FUSj_oC&pg=PA242 p. 242]. University Press of Kentucky (Lexington), 1987. Accessed 1 Aug 2013.</ref> In 1755, he survived the [[Draper's Meadow massacre]], an Indian attack against a settlement that was part of a property (later known as [[Smithfield (Blacksburg, Virginia)|Smithfield Plantation]]) that he inherited from his uncle, Colonel James Patton, who died in the incident.
Remaining in Virginia, William married Susanna Smith on January 17, 1761, and together they had 12 children. He and his family moved to Smithfield Plantation, in present-day [[Blacksburg, Virginia]], in 1774 and it served as his final home.<ref>Family Tree, Historic Smithfield Plantation Museum</ref> He previously resided at [[Greenfield (Fincastle, Virginia)|Greenfield Plantation]] at [[Fincastle, Virginia|Fincastle]], [[Botetourt County, Virginia]].<ref name=VAnom>{{cite web|url=http://www.dhr.virginia.gov/registers/Counties/Botetourt/011-0026_Greenfield_2010_NRHP_FINAL.pdf |title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory/Nomination: Greenfield |author=Michael J. Pulice & John R. Kern |date=April 2010}}</ref>
==Political and military life== Colonel Preston was elected to the Virginia colony's [[House of Burgesses]] in 1765 to represent [[Augusta County, Virginia|Augusta County]] and served until the county was divided around 1770.<ref>Johnson, Patricia Givens. ''William Preston and the Allegheny Patriots,'' 1976. pages 89–108</ref> In 1775, Preston was one of the thirteen signers of the [[Fincastle Resolutions]].
Colonel Preston served in both the [[French and Indian War]] and [[American Revolutionary War]]. During the French and Indian War, William Preston saved [[George Washington]]'s life from an impending Indian attack.<ref>spoken family history</ref> During [[Lord Dunmore's War]] of 1773-1774 against the [[Shawnee Indians]], he urged Virginians to join the militia to enact revenge on the Indians and plunder their stock of horses. As a Colonel in the militia, one of Colonel Preston's greatest contributions to the [[American Revolutionary War]] was his ability to suppress the [[Loyalist (American Revolution)|Tories]] (British loyalists) from uprising in Southwest Virginia, thus helping prevent a civil war during the Revolution. He also helped aid in the fight against [[Charles Cornwallis, 1st Marquess Cornwallis|Lord Cornwallis]] and the British in the Carolinas.<ref>''The Smithfield Review, Volume XII.'' "William Preston, Revolutionary (1779–1780)," Richard Osborn. pages 5–24</ref>
He served as a founding trustee of Liberty Hall, formerly the Augusta Academy, when in 1776 it was renamed in a burst of revolutionary fervor and relocated to [[Lexington, Virginia]].<ref name="wlu.edu">{{cite web|url=http://www.wlu.edu/x22.xml |title=A History :: Washington and Lee University |publisher=Wlu.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-02-28}}</ref><ref name="wlu.edu"/> Other founding trustees along with Preston were prominent men including [[Andrew Lewis (soldier)|Andrew Lewis]], [[Thomas Lewis (Virginia)|Thomas Lewis]], [[Samuel McDowell]], [[Sampson Mathews]], George Moffett, and [[James Waddel]].<ref name="Lex"/> Finally chartered in 1782, Liberty Hall was again renamed, to Washington College and finally [[Washington and Lee University]]. It is the ninth oldest institution of higher education in the country.<ref name="wlu.edu"/>
==Legacy== Colonel Preston died during a military muster near Price's Fork, Va., in 1783. The cause of death is unknown but it is believed to be either a heat stroke or a heart attack. He is buried in the family cemetery located on [[Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University|Virginia Tech]]'s campus in [[Blacksburg, Virginia]] near [[Smithfield (Blacksburg, Virginia)|Smithfield Plantation]]. His final home, [[Smithfield (Blacksburg, Virginia)|Smithfield Plantation]], has been restored and is listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places|U.S. Historical Registry]], and is open for tours April through the first week in December.
Many other prominent Americans descended from Colonel William Preston and his wife Susanna, for whom the plantation is named. They were parents or grandparents to governors, senators, presidential cabinet members, university founders and presidents, and military leaders. Most notably among them are the Prestons' son [[James Patton Preston]], who was governor of Virginia from 1816–1819 and helped charter the [[University of Virginia]], and their grandson [[William Ballard Preston]], who was a Congressman, Secretary of the Navy under [[Zachary Taylor]], and later a Senator from the Confederate States of America. William Ballard Preston also offered the Ordinance of Secession to the Virginia Legislature that resulted in Virginia joining the Confederacy, and he co-founded a small Methodist college, the [[Olin and Preston Institute]], which was in financial difficulty by 1872. The trustees relinquished its charter and donated its property to the state, which reorganized the campus as the Virginia Agricultural and Mechanical College, the forerunner what is today Virginia Tech.<ref>{{cite news | first=Duncan Lyle | last=Kinnear | title=A Short History of Virginia Tech | publisher= | url =http://spec.lib.vt.edu/archives/125th/kinnear/prefound.htm | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2017-09-15 | language = }}</ref>
Colonel Preston was memorialized on July 27, 2011 with the Colonel William Preston highway in [[Blacksburg, Virginia]].
The city of [[Prestonville, Kentucky]], was erected on one of his land grants and named in his honor. It was (before 1800) the most important town in the county and larger than [[Carrollton, Kentucky|Port William]]. One of the first roads built in this section of the state was from the mouth of the Kentucky to [[New Castle, Kentucky|New Castle]] in [[Henry County, Kentucky|Henry County]].
==Further reading== *The Smithfield Review, Volumes I-XV. *Johnson, Patricia Givens, ''William Preston and the Allegheny Patriots''. 1976 *Osborn, Richard Charles, ''William Preston of Virginia, 1727–1783: The Making of a Frontier Elite''. UMI Dissertation Services. 1990
==See also==
* [[William Preston (poet)]] * [[Thomas Preston, 1st Viscount Tara]]
